expanded_description: OR compound inequalities represent situations where a value can satisfy either one condition or the other (or both). The solution is the union of the two individual solution sets. Unlike AND inequalities, which give a single connected interval, OR inequalities often result in two separate regions on the number line.

core_concept.principle: An 'or' compound inequality, such as $x < 2$ or $x > 5$, means that $x$ can satisfy either condition. The solution is the set of values that are less than 2 OR greater than 5. Graphically, this shows as two separate shaded regions on the number line—one to the left of 2 and one to the right of 5.
core_concept.explanation: Think of 'or' compound inequalities as a restaurant menu offering two options: you can choose the chicken OR the fish. Either choice is acceptable. On a number line, it's like having two separate parking lots—you can park in either one, and both are valid options.

key_concept.definition: A compound inequality with 'or' has the form $x < a$ or $x > b$ (or similar). The solution is the set of numbers that satisfy at least one of the inequalities. This is the union of the two solution sets, often resulting in two separate intervals on the number line.
key_concept.context: OR inequalities represent alternatives or options—like 'you must be under 12 or over 65 for the discount'—where meeting either condition qualifies.

worked_examples.title: Identifying OR Compound Inequalities

image.alt: Various inequality statements
image.caption: Figure 6.7.7: Identify which are OR compound inequalities.

worked_examples.problem:
Which of the following are OR compound inequalities? For those that are, describe the solution in words.
a) $x < -2$ or $x > 5$
b) $x \geq 3$ and $x \leq 7$
c) $x \leq 0$ or $x \geq 10$
d) $2 < x < 6$
e) $x < 1$ or $x < 4$

step_by_step.calculation: Numbers less than -2 OR greater than 5

worked_examples.final_answer: a) OR: $x < -2$ or $x > 5$, b) Not OR, c) OR: $x \leq 0$ or $x \geq 10$, d) Not OR, e) OR but simplifies to $x < 4$
worked_examples.concept_applied: OR inequalities use 'or' and represent the union of conditions.

sections.introduction: Solving an OR compound inequality means finding the union of the solution sets of the individual inequalities.

key_concept.definition: To solve an OR compound inequality, solve each inequality separately. The solution is the union of the two solution sets. Graphically, you shade both regions on the number line.
key_concept.context: Unlike AND inequalities, there's no compact form for OR inequalities (except when they simplify to a single interval).

image.alt: Example: 2x + 1 < 5 or 3x - 2 > 7 solved separately
image.caption: Figure 6.7.10: Solving separate OR inequalities.

image.alt: OR inequalities to solve
image.caption: Figure 6.7.11: Solve each OR inequality.

worked_examples.problem:
Solve each compound inequality and graph the solution:
a) $2x + 1 < 5$ or $3x - 2 > 7$
b) $4x - 3 \leq 5$ or $2x + 1 \geq 9$
c) $\frac{x}{2} - 1 < 2$ or $2x + 3 > 7$
d) $5 - 2x > 3$ or $3x + 4 \leq 10$

image.caption: Figure 6.7.15: x ≤ 2.

worked_examples.final_answer: a) $x < 2$ or $x > 3$, b) $x \leq 2$ or $x \geq 4$, c) All real numbers, d) $x \leq 2$
worked_examples.concept_applied: Solve each inequality separately, then combine as a union. Watch for overlaps that simplify the result.

process_flow.description: Treat each inequality separately and find its solution set.
process_flow.mechanism: Use inverse operations, flipping signs when multiplying/dividing by negatives.

image.caption: Figure 6.7.17: Step 2 - Combine as union.

process_flow.description: Shade all regions that are part of the solution set.

sections.introduction: OR inequalities can lead to special cases where the solution is all real numbers or simplifies to a single interval.

introduction_image.alt: Special cases: all real numbers, single interval
introduction_image.caption: Figure 6.7.20: Special cases in OR inequalities.

key_concept.definition: If the solution sets overlap or cover the entire number line, the OR inequality may simplify. If one condition is always true whenever the other is true, the less restrictive condition determines the solution. If the two conditions together cover all real numbers, the solution is all real numbers.
key_concept.context: Recognizing these cases can simplify your answer and help avoid unnecessary complexity.

sections.introduction: Understanding the difference between AND and OR compound inequalities is crucial. Let's compare them directly.

introduction_image.caption: Figure 6.7.31: Comparing AND and OR inequalities.

key_concept.definition:
AND: Both conditions must be true. Graph is a single interval between two endpoints. Compact form: $a < x < b$.
OR: At least one condition must be true. Graph often shows two separate regions. No compact form (unless simplified to one interval).
key_concept.context: Choosing the right connective is essential for correctly modeling real-world situations.

image.alt: Comparison table of AND and OR properties
image.caption: Figure 6.7.32: AND vs OR comparison.

For each situation, determine whether AND or OR should connect the conditions:

b) You can pay with cash or credit card.
c) The temperature must be above freezing and below boiling.

e) Employees must have 5 years experience or a college degree.

summary: OR compound inequalities represent the union of two conditions—a value can satisfy either one. To solve, treat each inequality separately and combine their solution sets. The graph typically shows two separate shaded regions, though overlapping conditions may simplify to a single interval or all real numbers. Special cases occur when one condition is contained within the other (e.g., $x > 3$ or $x > 7$ simplifies to $x > 3$) or when the union covers the entire number line (e.g., $x \geq 0$ or $x \leq 5$ gives all real numbers). Real-world applications include alternative eligibility criteria (child or senior discount), extreme conditions (below freezing or above boiling), and optional payment methods. Unlike AND inequalities, OR inequalities cannot be written in a compact form with the variable in the middle (unless they simplify to a single interval). Understanding the difference between AND and OR is essential for correctly modeling and solving real-world problems.
